K. Pallavi vs Shaheen Begum on 18 November, 2022

Author: P.Naveen Rao

Bench: P.Naveen Rao

              HON'BLE SRI JUSTICE P.NAVEEN RAO

      CIVIL REVISION PETITION NOs.2400 & 2401 OF 2022


                          Date: 18.11.2022

                                                                              PNR,J
                                                        CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022
                                      2


                HON'BLE SRI JUSTICE P.NAVEEN RAO

       CIVIL REVISION PETITION NOs.2400 & 2401 OF 2022

COMMON ORDER:

(Per Hon'ble Sri Justice P.Naveen Rao) The Election Original Petition is filed alleging that the respondent no.1 is liable to be disqualified for contesting GHMC elections as she has nine children and that as per Section 21-B of the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation Act (GHMC), the candidate with more than two children is not eligible to contest the GHMC elections. The petitioner has given the date of births of nine children, names of eight children and the hospitals where the children were born allegedly to respondent no.1. The evidence was closed and matter is at the stage of submission of oral arguments.

2. At that stage, I.A.No.4732 of 2022 is filed by the petitioner under Order XVI Rule 6 read with Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC) to issue summons to the respondent no.1 and to one Mohammed Azhar for presenting themselves in person before the Tribunal for the limited purpose of collecting their blood samples for DNA finger printing/comparison in open Court for determining the maternity of Mohammed Azhar.

3. I.A.No.4736 of 2022 is filed by the petitioner under Order XXVI Rule 10A read with Section 151 of CPC seeking a direction to refer the blood samples of the respondent no.1 and Mohammed Azhar to the PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 3 Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology, Hyderabad, for conducting DNA finger printing/comparison for determining the maternity of Mohammed Azhar.

4. On elaborate consideration of respective submissions and precedent decisions the Election Tribunal dismissed both IAs. These two revisions are filed challenging the Orders of the Election Tribunal in both IAs.

5. Heard learned counsel Sri Rakesh Sanghi for the petitioner and the learned counsel Sri Kishore Rai for the respondents. 6.1. Learned counsel Sri Rakesh Sanghi would contend that 1st respondent gave false declaration on number of children she gave birth. Though she was having nine children she disclosed only two as her children. Therefore, her election has to be declared as void. He would submit that the petitioner came to know that she has one more child by name Md.Azhar. With great difficulty, the petitioner could secure Aadhaar Card of the person. Aadhaar Card discloses the name of husband of 1st respondent and residential address mentioned therein belongs to the respondent. In view of this discovery, petitioner filed I.A.Nos.4734 and 4736 of 2002. He would submit that the Court below erred in not granting reliefs prayed in the two IAs. 6.2. He would submit that there is no indefeasible right to refuse giving blood samples and to undergo DNA test which are required to PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 4 determine that Md.Azhar is biological son of 1st respondent. According to learned counsel, the Aadhaar Card secured by petitioner points out that Md.Azhar is son of 1st respondent and, therefore, these tests are necessary to elicit information.

6.3. He would submit that merely looking at the date of birth shown in Aadhaar Card, it cannot be presumed that the gap between 5th child and Md.Azhar is less than five months. It is possible to tamper the date of birth entering in Aadhaar Card and, therefore, it is not conclusive proof to come to the conclusion that within less than five months another child could not have been born. 6.4. Learned counsel placed reliance on following decisions:

i) Gopala Krishna Murthyv. Ramchander Rao and others1;
ii) G.Prayag Raj v. Sreevani @ Vani2;
iii) Sharda v. Dharmpal3;
iv) Haryana Financial Corporation and another v. Jagdamba Oil Mills and another4;
v) Ashok Kumar v. Raj Gupta and others5

7.1. Per contra, learned counsel for 1st respondent would submit that in paragraph (iv) of the Election Petition, petitioner has shown that 1st respondent has nine children with names, date of births and place of birth, but is silent on name of Md.Azhar as son of the 1st respondent. 1 AIR 1973 AP 309 2 2013 (2) ALD 276 3 (2003) 4 SCC 493 4 (2002) 3 SCC 496 5 (2022) 1 SCC 20 PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 5 It is not stated how he is asserting that Md.Azhar is son of the 1st respondent. By pointing out to entries in Aadhaar Card he would submit that what is shown is 'care of' of husband of 1st respondent and not as son of. Further, merely because residential address of 1st respondent is given in the Aadhaar Card it cannot be presumed that Md.Azhar is son of 1st respondent.

7.2. He would submit that matter is coming for arguments. The petitioner is not interested in early conclusion of the Election Petition and is dragging on the matter by filing interlocutory applications again and again.

7.3. He would submit that it is highly improbable to have a child within five months of birth of a child whereas petitioner stated in Election Petition that Nousheeda Begum was 5th child born on06.05.2002, whereas date of birth of Md.Azhar is shown as 27.09.2002.

7.4. Learned counsel relied on the following decision:

i) Pukhrem Sharatchandra Singh Vs. Mairembam Prithviraj6

8. The issue for consideration is can the Election Tribunal order to take blood samples of a person unconcerned with the Election Petition and to subject him to DNA test ?

6 (2015) 16 SCC 149 PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 6

9. In SANTOSH YADAV v. NARENDER SINGH7 and BALDEV SINGH MANN vs. SURJIT SINGH DHIMAN8, Supreme Court held that standard of proof is high and burden of proof is on the election petitioner to prove an allegation of fraud or misrepresentation earning disqualification of elected candidate. Mere preponderance of probabilities are not enough, as may be the case in a civil dispute. Allegations should be clear and precise and charge should be proved to the hilt as in a criminal trial by clear, cogent and credible evidence. In SANTOSH YADAV, Supreme Court summarized the principles on improper acceptance of nominations. It is held that case has to be made out by raising specific pleadings setting out all material facts and adducing cogent evidence so as to enable a clear finding being arrived at. The burden of proving such material fact has to be discharged by the election petitioner by adducing positive, satisfactory and cogent evidence. If petitioner is unable to adduce such evidence the burden is not discharged and the election must stand. Difficulty of proof cannot obviate the need of strict proof or relax the rigour of required proof. The burden of proof placed on the election petitioner is very strict and so difficult to discharge as nearing almost impossibility. There is no room for any guesswork, speculation, surmises or conjectures i.e., acting on a mere possibility. The law requires proof. How far that proof should go or what it should contain is not provided by the legislature. 7 (2002) 1 SCC 160 8 AIR 2009 SC 1045 PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 7

10. In B.RAVI YADAV VS. CHERKULA UDAY KUMAR AND OTHERS9, Division Bench of this Court held as under :

"...To prove the charge of corrupt practice a mere preponderance of probabilities would not be enough. There would be a presumption of innocence available to the person charged. The charge shall have to be proved to the hilt, the standard of proof being the same as in a criminal trial. It is further held by the Apex Court that the success of a candidate who has won at an election should not be lightly interfered with. Any petition seeking such interference must strictly conform to the requirements of the law. Though the purity of the election process has to be safeguarded and the Court shall be vigilant to see that people do not get elected by flagrant breaches of law or by committing corrupt practices, the setting aside of an election involves serious consequences not only for the returned candidate and the constituency, but also for the public at large inasmuch as re-election involves an enormous load on the public funds and administration."

11. The above decisions are followed by this Court in LAGADAPATI RAJA GOPAL Vs. SUNKARA KRISHNA MURTHY AND OTHERS10. This Court held It is not the same thing as proof which comes later that the Court has to find whether the accused is guilty. It signifies that on first examination the matter appears to be self evident from the facts. In common law jurisprudence, prima facie case denotes evidence which (unless rebutted) would be sufficient to prove a particular proposition or fact. It is further held:

"The Court has to be watchful and ensure that conjectures or suspicions do not take the place of legal proof, but at the time of framing charge in a criminal case, what is required to be seen is whether the charge-sheet and the documents relied upon including the FIR and the statement of witnesses, if accepted as true at that stage 9 2013 (1) ALD 733 (DB) 10 2010 (5) ALD 758 PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 8 would constitute a prima facie case. Prima facie evidence means, on the face of it, there is a ground for proceeding. It is not the same thing as proof which comes later that the Court has to find whether the accused is guilty. It signifies that on first examination the matter appears to be self evident from the facts. In common law jurisprudence, prima facie case denotes evidence which (unless rebutted) would be sufficient to prove a particular proposition or fact."

12. R.RAJAGOPAL ALIAS R.R.GOPAL AND ANOTHER VS. STATE OF TAMIL NADU AND OTHERS11 is a case concerning right of privacy vis-a- vis freedom of press. Supreme Court summarized broad principles and held as under:

"26. We may now summarise the broad principles flowing from the above discussion:
(1) The right to privacy is implicit in the right to life and liberty guaranteed to the citizens of this country by Article 21. It is a right to be let alone. A citizen has a right to safeguard the privacy of his own, his family, marriage, procreation, motherhood, child-bearing and education among other matters. None can publish anything concerning the above matters without his consent whether truthful or otherwise and whether laudatory or critical. If he does so, he would be violating the right to privacy of the person concerned and would be liable in an action for damages. Position may, however, be different, if a person voluntarily thrusts himself into controversy or voluntarily invites or raises a controversy."

13. In SELVI AND OTHERS Vs STATE OF KARNATAKA12, Supreme Court on review of the entire case law on issue of subjecting a person to Narcoanalysis, polygraph test (lie-detector test) and BEAP (Brain Electrical Activation Profile) test, held that test results cannot be 11 1994 (6) SCC 632 12 2010 (7) SCC 263 PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 9 admitted in evidence if they have been obtained through the use of compulsion. Article 20(3) protects an individuals choice between speaking and remaining silent, irrespective of whether the subsequent testimony proves to be inculpatory or exculpatory. Article 20(3) aims to prevent the forcible conveyance of personal knowledge that is relevant to the facts in issue. The results obtained from each of the impugned tests bear a testimonial character and they cannot be categorized as material evidence. It is further held that, 'We have also elaborated how the compulsory administration of any of these techniques is an unjustified intrusion into the mental privacy of an individual. It would also amount to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment with regard to the language of evolving international human rights norms'. (para 263). It is further held that no individual should be forcibly subjected to any of the techniques in question, whether in the contest of investigation in criminal cases or otherwise. Doing so would amount to an unwarranted intrusion into personal liberty. (para 264).

14. The petitioner challenges the election of 1st respondent as Corporator on the ground that she is having nine children and, therefore, earned disqualification to contest as Corporator under Section 21-B of Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation Act. Petitioner contends that having come to know that 1st respondent is having nine children, during the scrutiny of nomination she orally raised objection, but same was not considered. After the election also, objection was raised with respondents 7 to 9, but no action was taken.

PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 10 Petitioner claimed to have secured birth certificates of nine children. Petitioner filed the Election Petition by relying on the information secured by her. In the E.P. petitioner listed out names of eight children, dates of birth of nine children and hospitals where children were born. It is alleged that 1st respondent gave false declaration on number of children born to her and number of dependants.

15. In the IAs filed by the petitioner, petitioner now contends that the 1st respondent is having one more son by name Mohammed Azhar. Petitioner relies on Aadhaar Card to support his contention that Md. Azhar is her son. Name of Mohammed Azhar was not shown in the list of children mentioned in the Election Petition. He now asserts that this information was secured only recently.

16. According to learned counsel for petitioner, even though Mohammed Azhar is not a party to the Election Petition, he can be summoned as a witness and his blood samples can be collected. In support of this submission, learned counsel relied on the decision of this Court in GOPALA KRISHNA MURTHY case.

17. In the said decision, learned Judge observed that a person need not be a party to summon to give evidence. Learned Judge relied on a decision of Patna High Court. Patna High Court (extracted herein) held that a request to summon a witness can be rejected if it was not made bona fide, abuse of the process of the Court or vexatious. Paragraph-9 reads as under:

PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 11 "9. In Basant Narain v. State of Bihar, [A.I.R. 1958 Patna 458] V. Ramaswami, C.J. and R.K. Choudhary, J. observed thus in construing the provisions of Order 16, Rule 1 C.P.C.
"The law, therefore, is perfectly clear that as matter of general rule the Court is bound to issue summons to the witnesses if an application is made for summoning them at any time after, the institution of the suit and before its decision and the Court is not entitled to refuse to issue summons to the witnesses on the ground that the application was made at a very late stage though the Court is not bound in all cases to adjourn the hearing of the case to enable the witnesses to attend on the dale of the hearing. "But there is an exception to this general rule and that exception is that where the Court thinks that the prayer for issue of summons to witnesses has not been made bona fide or has been made as an abuse to the process of the Court or the prayer is vexatious, it has got inherent jurisdiction to refuse the prayer. The power is inherent in the jurisdiction of every Court of justice to protect itself from the abuse of its own procedure".

18. In the counter-affidavit, 1st respondent denied the contention of petitioner that she has nine children and asserted that she has only two children. The first respondent further asserted that earlier three Election Petitions were filed against her and her husband leveling the allegation that they have more than two children and all the Election Petitions were dismissed.

19. From the Aadhaar Card standing in the name of Mohammed Azhar it is seen that name of Mohd. Shareef is mentioned as 'care of' and the residential address is that of 1st respondent. Except these two entries in the Aadhaar Card no other document is filed to show prima facie that Mohammed Azhar is son of 1st respondent. It cannot be said that merely because Aadhaar Card contains the residential address of first respondent and name of her husband is shown as 'care of', it cannot be assumed that Mohammed Azhar is her son. Further, discrepancy pointed out on the date of birth shown in the Aadhaar PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 12 Card. In the list of children mentioned in the Election Petition, 5th child was stated to have born on 06.05.2002. In the Aadhaar Card the person date of birth is shown as 27.09.2002. Thus, there cannot be child born within five months. Having realized this discrepancy petitioner sought to assert that the Aadhaar Card could have been manipulated. In the absence of any other material to prima facie point out that Mohammed Azhar is son of 1st respondent, the Election Tribunal has not accepted the plea of the petitioner.

20. Right to privacy is implicit in right to life and liberty as enshrined in Article 21 of the Constitution of India. No person's privacy can be invaded much against the consent and will of that person. Certain exceptions to this rigid principle are carved out where larger public interest is involved and in matters concerning matrimonial disputes. It is held that a person who is alleged to have been suffering with HIV disease can be subjected to medical examination even against his will as it is necessary to know his medical condition since it is likely to affect life of others also. Similarly, in personal law concerning relationship of husband and wife and the children born to such wedlock, the right to privacy is invaded to ascertain whether the marriage was consumed properly, whether the spouses to the marriage are suitable to live together or suffering from any disease which disentitles them to live as husband and wife. In matters where a marriage is sought to be nullified also it may be necessary to ascertain the health of one of the spouses of the marriage etc. To ascertain the PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 13 birth of a child to the couple, DNA test can be ordered. Similarly, when it comes to the custody of a child, the mental condition of the spouse is also necessarily to be ascertained before Court orders the custody of the child to one of the parents. In all such circumstances, subjecting a person to medical examination does not amount to violating right of privacy. These are exceptions to normal rule.

21. SHARDA, ASHOK KUMAR and G.PRAYAG RAJ concern Matrimonial disputes.

22. In SHARDA, an application was filed seeking direction for medical examination of the respondent. The question that fell for consideration by the Supreme Court was whether the party to divorce proceedings can be compelled to medical examination. Supreme Court held as under:

"32. Yet again the primary duty of a court is to see that truth is arrived at. A party to a civil litigation, it is axiomatic, is not entitled to constitutional protections under Article 20 of the Constitution of India. Thus, the civil court although may not have any specific provisions in the Code of Civil Procedure and the Evidence Act, has an inherent power in terms of Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure to pass all orders for doing complete justice to the parties to the suit.
33. Discretionary power under Section 151 of the Code of Civil Procedure, it is trite, can be exercised also on an application filed by the party.
34. In certain cases medical examination by the experts in the field may not only be found to be leading to the truth of the matter but may also lead to removal of misunderstanding between the parties. It may bring the parties to terms.
35. Having regard to development in medicinal technology, it is possible to find out that what was presumed to be a mental disorder of a spouse is not really so.
36. In matrimonial disputes, the court has also a conciliatory role to play even for the said purpose it may require expert advice.
37. Under Section 75(e) of the Code of Civil Procedure and Order 26 Rule 10-A the civil court has the requisite power to issue a direction to hold a scientific, technical or expert investigation."

PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 14

23. In ASHOK KUMAR, after reviewing precedent decisions, Hon'ble Supreme Court opined as under:

"14. It was also the view of the Court that the normal rule of evidence is that the burden is on the party that asserts the positive. But in instances where that is challenged, the burden is shifted to the party, that pleads the negative. Keeping in mind the issue of burden of proof, it would be safe to conclude that in a case like the present, the court's decision should be rendered only after balancing the interests of the parties i.e. the quest for truth, and the social and cultural implications involved therein. The possibility of stigmatising a person as a bastard, the ignominy that attaches to an adult who, in the mature years of his life is shown to be not the biological son of his parents may not only be a heavy cross to bear but would also intrude upon his right of privacy.
15. DNA is unique to an individual (barring twins) and can be used to identify a person's identity, trace familial linkages or even reveal sensitive health information. Whether a person can be compelled to provide a sample for DNA in such matters can also be answered considering the test of proportionality laid down in the unanimous decision of this Court in K.S. Puttaswamy (Aadhaar-5 J.) v. Union of India [K.S. Puttaswamy (Aadhaar-5 J.) v. Union of India, (2019) 1 SCC 1] , wherein the right to privacy has been declared a constitutionally protected right in India. The Court should therefore examine the proportionality of the legitimate aims being pursued i.e. whether the same are not arbitrary or discriminatory, whether they may have an adverse impact on the person and that they justify the encroachment upon the privacy and personal autonomy of the person, being subjected to the DNA test.
16. It cannot be overlooked that in the present case, the application to subject the plaintiff to a DNA test is in a declaratory suit and the plaintiff has already adduced evidence and is not interested to produce additional evidence (DNA), to prove his case. It is now the turn of the defendants to adduce their evidence. At this stage, they are asking for subjecting the plaintiff to a DNA test. Questioning the timing of the application the trial court dismissed the defendants' application and we feel that it was the correct order."

24. As held by the Supreme Court in SANTOSH YADAV and BALDEV SINGH MANN and this Court in LAGADAPATI RAJA GOPAL, in election matters the standard of proof is high and burden is on the election petitioner. Mere preponderance of probabilities or presumptions cannot be the basis to challenge an election. The election proceedings are akin to criminal proceedings. In view of the above proposition of law on the PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 15 subject, the burden lies on the petitioner to make specific allegation and lead evidence in support of said allegation. Petitioner in Election Petition cannot assume that Md.Azhar was born to 1st respondent and seek to elicit such information by subjecting a non-party to the election dispute to medical examination.

25. In R.RAJAGOPAL (supra), Supreme Court held that a citizen has a right to safeguard the privacy of procreation, motherhood, child bearing, parent status and education among others.

26. A woman has a right to be silent, not to disclose about giving birth to a child. No person can compel a woman to give up this right much against her will. The case on hand does not fall into the exceptions carved out to the principle on right to privacy. Further, there is no prima facie material to point out with some amount of certainty that Mohammed Azhar is son of 1st respondent. As of now, he is a stranger to the election dispute. A wrong declaration and a resultant disqualification relates to the first respondent. Mohammed Azhar is no way concerned. Thus, he cannot be compelled to stand as a witness to give blood samples to ascertain parental status. Certainly subjecting Mohammed Azhar to medical examination would offend his personal liberty, privacy and dignity. Further, it also offends personal liberty, privacy and dignity that is bestowed on first respondent as a woman. There can be many reasons where a woman would genuinely wish to keep the issue of giving birth to a child not disclosed assuming PNR,J CRP Nos.2400 & 2401 of 2022 16 the fact is true. By subjecting 1st respondent and Md.Azhar to medical examination at the instance of the petitioner in election petition, the factum of giving birth to or otherwise would be in public domain and would be against the conscience and will of the person concerned and can have deleterious effect on the 1st respondent and also on Mohammed Azhar which cannot be remedied. The consequence of such medical examination can be far and wide.

27. The learned Election Tribunal has not committed any error in dismissing the I.As., warranting interference. The two Civil Revision Petitions are dismissed. Pending miscellaneous applications if any shall stand closed.
